metadata.synopsis: Agent Jack Ryan (Harrison Ford) becomes acting deputy director of the CIA when Admiral Greer (James Earl Jones) is diagnosed with cancer. When an American businessman, and friend of the president, is murdered on a yacht, Ryan starts discovering links between the man and drug dealers. As CIA agent John Clark (Willem Dafoe) is sent to Colombia to kill drug kingpins in retaliation, Ryan must fight through multiple cover-ups to figure out what happened and who's responsible.

reviews: This is a guy movie; jam-packed with politics, CIA scheming, special forces sniping, and a smart bomb dropped by an F/A-18 Hornet fighter jet on a Colombian drug lord's daughter's quinceañera. In other words, a REAL murder Hornet.
Plot suffocates the film. Simply too much happens.
The premise is a fairly standard backstabbing and covert operations blend, but the details are substantial.
In both novel and film, Ryan is the moral centre, but the film jettisons the book's range of supporting characters whose differing values help define his position.

both cutting in its indictment of how power corrupts even the best intentions and bravely optimistic in asserting that, not only can one maintain one's sense of honor and integrity in a rigged system, but very possibly make all the difference in the world
'90s book-based political thriller has violence, language.
Having figured out how to make a Jack Ryan action thriller with Patriot Games, the same cluster of filmmakers got to do it again... managing to improve virtually across the board.
Ford's second and final appearance as Jack Ryan is a sprawling thriller.
Well crafted if utterly conventional action thriller (third in Tom Clancy's series), whose best asset is Harrison Ford's star turn.
None of it is uplifting or tells us something fresh, but it passes as easy viewing entertainment.

This is the third movie with Jack as its hero, so he is a known quantity -- a humanist spook with an overdeveloped moral sense -- but Ford, playing the part for the second time, knows how to keep his earnestness fresh.
It's a formula film with a typically dubious political message, but the storytelling is livelier and more engaging than previous adaptations of Clancy's turgid techno-thrillers.
Narrative complexity and momentum make this a true cinematic equivalent of an absorbing page-turner.
High energy Harrison Ford in another installment of spy series.
There's a glimmer of interest in the film's ideological contortions, but as a commercial action thriller this is inflated and sluggish.
Best of Ford's Jack Ryan movies: taut and tough.
